title: evoTS: analysis of evolutionary sequences of phenotypic change
text: evoTS package facilitates univariate multivariate analysis evolutionary sequences phenotypic change. goal evoTS package offer large range evolutionary models enable detailed studies evolutionary change within lineages, fossil record modern lineages. evoTS package extends univariate modeling framework implemented paleoTS package (Hunt 2006; 2008a; 2008b; Hunt et al. 2008; 2010; 2015) containing functions fit large range univariate evolutionary models implemented paleoTS. evoTS developed mirror user experience paleoTS much possible. example, univariate models implemented evoTS can fitted paleoTS object, .e. data format used paleoTS. fit univariate models available paleoTS evoTS directly comparable. evoTS contains range multivariate models, including different versions multivariate unbiased random walks Ornstein-Uhlenbeck processes. Together, models allow user test various hypotheses trait evolution, e.g. whether traits change correlated uncorrelated manner, whether one trait/variable affects optimum second trait (Granger causality), whether adaptation different traits happen independently toward fixed optima etc. evoTS also contains functions calculating topology likelihood surfaces fitted models, useful feature investigate range parameter values approximately equal likelihood best parameter estimates.

title: evoTS: analysis of evolutionary sequences of phenotypic change
text: object class paleoTS required input functions evoTS. create paleoTS object, need vectors trait means, sample/population variances, sample sizes ages samples/populations. One easy way create paleoTS object use .paleoTS function paleoTS package. Another way get data evoTS use function read.paleoTS paleoTS package. function imports data text file four columns corresponding trait means, sample/population variances, sample sizes ages samples/populations, converts input paleoTS object. See also paleoTS (vignette) info import data create paleoTS object.
code: ## Creating example data  > trait_means<-rnorm(20) > trait_variance<-rep(0.5,20) > sample_size<-rep(30,20) > time_vector<-seq(0,19,1)  # Create paleoTS object > indata.evoTS<-paleoTS::as.paleoTS(mm = trait_means, vv = trait_variance, nn = sample_size, tt = time_vector)

title: evoTS: analysis of evolutionary sequences of phenotypic change
text: Two evolutionary sequences (time-series) phenotypic change included evoTS package. data diatom lineage Stephanodiscus yellowstonensis originally published Theriot et al. (2006). trait consists 63 samples spanning almost 14 000 years phenotypic change. use data illustrate many functions implemented evoTS. first investigate phenotypic change diameter S. yellowstonensis. diameter measured micrometers, interested investigating proportional changes trait. therefore first approximate log-transformation data. convert time vector data set unit length (.e. length time oldest youngest sample/population data set becomes 1). linear transformation time vector change estimated parameters describe evolutionary dynamics data, ease parameter estimation interpretation certain model parameters. also plot data look phenotypic changes.
code: ## Doing an approximate log-transformation of the data > ln.diameter<-paleoTS::ln.paleoTS(diameter_S.yellowstonensis)  ## Convert the time vector to unit length > ln.diameter$tt<-ln.diameter$tt/(max(ln.diameter$tt))  ## Plotting the data > plotpaleoTS(ln.diameter)

title: evoTS: analysis of evolutionary sequences of phenotypic change
text: evoTS package contains range univariate models supplement models available paleoTS. paleoTS package contains functions fit biased (GRW) unbiased random walks (URW), stasis (modeled white noise process, .e. uncorrelated variation around constant mean), strict stasis (real evolutionary change) Ornstein-Uhlenbeck (OU) processes assuming fixed optimum (see Hunt 2006 Hunt et al. 2008 info models). paleoTS package also contains models punctuated mode evolution punctuations (jumps phenotype space) separate different parameterizations stasis model (Hunt 2008). paleoTS package also contains mode shift models, .e. model evolution shifts point evolutionary sequence (Hunt 2008; Hunt et al. 2015). Several new univariate models implemented evoTS package. Functions also available fit mode shifts univariate models available evoTS paleoTS combined. also functions available evoTS allow one mode shift analyzed evolutionary sequence. following univariate models implemented evoTS package: decerelated-evolution model (unbiased random walk exponential decrease rate change time) accelerated-evolution model (unbiased random walk exponential increase rate change time) Bokma model (punctuated equilibrium model two (three) unbiased random walks separated one (two) jump(s)/punctuation(s) morphospace) Ornstein-Uhlenbeck processes optimum changes according unbiased random walk.

title: evoTS: analysis of evolutionary sequences of phenotypic change
text: Multivariate Ornstein-Uhlenbeck models allow testing range different adaptive hypotheses trait evolution, detailed . Adapted describe evolution traits within lineage, multivariate Ornstein-Uhlenbeck process described following differential equation (Bartoszek et al. 2012; Reitan et al. 2012; Clavel et al. 2015): \[dY = (\theta(t)-Y(t))dt + RdW(t)\]  square matrix dimensions equal number investigated traits describes rate evolution toward optimal trait values (often called pull matrix), \(\theta\) vector containing optimum trait, R square matrix dimensions equal number investigated traits describing stochastic changes traits (R often called drift matrix), \(W\) diffusion parameter. assumption one selective regime (optimum) per trait, expected trait mean Ornstein-Uhlenbeck process weighted sum optimum root value (Hansen 1997): \[E\left[Z_{}\right]= e^{(-At_{})}z_{0} + (1-e^{(-At_{})}\theta)\]  \(Z_{}\) expected trait value sample , \(z_{0}\) ancestral trait mean, Θ optimum, pull matrix measuring rate adaptation optimum, \(t_{}\) time interval ancestral population mean (start time-series, time 0) ith population mean. variance covariance sample/population means given following expression: \[Cov(z_{}, z_{j})=\left[P\left( \left[ \frac{1}{\lambda_{k} + \lambda_{l}} \left( 1-e^{-({\lambda_{k} + \lambda_{l})}t_{}}\right)\right]_{1\le kl \le m}   \odot P^{-1}\Sigma\Sigma^{T}(P^{-1})^{T}\right) P^{T}\right]e^{-^{T}t_{ij}}\]  P orthogonal matrix eigenvectors , \(\Sigma\Sigma^{T}\) Cholesky decomposition R matrix, \(\lambda_{}\) ith eigenvalue , \(t_{}\) time interval ancestral population oldest two populations \(z_{}\) \(z_{j}\), \(t_{ij}\) time separating two samples \(z_{}\) \(z_{j}\), \(\odot\) represents Hadamard (element-wise) product. Different ways parameterize matrix allows testing range evolutionary hypotheses using multivariate OU process. R matrix multivariate version unbiased random walk (multivariate OU model) either needs diagonal (elements diagonal -diagonal elements zero) complete (sense diagonal -diagonal elements non-zero), case matrix. Generally, can divide hypotheses tested using multivariate OU four different types: Independent evolution (diagonal elements R matrix, .e. equivalent fitting univariate models trait separately.) Independent adaptation (diagonal elements matrix R matrix completely parameterized. model, traits adapting independently toward optima, stochastic changes traits correlated.) least one trait affects optimum trait. diagonal least one -diagonal elements matrix non-zero. trait column non-zero -diagonal element affects optimum trait row non-zero -diagonal element. negative -diagonal element means trait evolves toward optimum determined trait, positive -diagonal element means trait evolve away optimum determined trait. stochastic changes trait can either correlated non-correlated. traits affect others optimum (different degrees). -diagonal elements sides diagonal parameterized matrix. stochastic changes trait can either correlated non-correlated.  matrix -diagonal elements investigates (Granger) causality two traits/variables (Granger 1969; Schweder 1970). Simply speaking, evidence Granger causality observations one time series useful forecasting observations one several time series, case one trait affects optimum another trait tracks lag. Multivariate OU models therefore enable us move beyond interpreting correlations among variables. correlation measure linear dependence two random variables, time dimension (.e. lag/evolutionary inertia tracking changing optimum) potential relationship two variables important Granger causality. correlation symmetric (correlation X Y correlation Y X), necessarily case Granger causality. X can (Granger) cause Y, without Y Granger-causing X. data set consisting two traits, four possible parameterizations matrix (see panels ). Independent adaptation traits (panel ), trait Y affecting optimum trait X (panel b), trait X affecting optimum trait Y, traits X Y affecting others optima (panel d). four ways parameterizing matrix can combined R matrix elements diagonal (stochastic changes traits uncorrelated) completely parameterized R matrix (stochastic changes traits correlated). also possible implement model last trait data set evolves unbiased random walk affects optima traits data set. model can fitted defining .matrix ="OUBM", sets last diagonal element matrix zero. zero diagonal element matrix means tendency trait evolve towards optimal value (case unbiased random walk). Setting .matrix ="OUBM" automatically define R matrix diagonal elements (.e. option matrix override R matrix defined user). Multivariate Ornstein-Uhlenbeck models can fitted using two different functions evoTS. function fit.multivariate.OU allows user use pre-defined arguments R matrices parameterize matrices. .matrix can either defined “diag” (panel ), “upper.tri” (panel b ), “lower.tri” (panel c ), “full” (panel d ). Default “diag”. R.matrix can defined “diag” “symmetric”. function fit.multivariate.OU.user.defined lets user define elements R matrices parameterized. function allows full flexibility type hypotheses tested parameterization constrained follow pre-defined options matrix available function fit.multivariate.OU. investigate whether two traits S. yellowstonensis lineage show evidence independent evolution (diagonal elements R matrices) whether adaptation part trait dynamics independent two traits (diagonal matrix symmetric R matrix). test hypotheses using fit.multivariate.OU function. model independent adaptation correlated stochastic changes much better independent evolution model. half-life log diameter log number ribs 6.1% 4.9% length time-series, translates (13728 * 0.061 =) 837 (13728 * 0.049 =) 673 years respectively. correlation stochastic changes substantial, much reduced compared estimate correlation multivariate unbiased random walk. substantial part trait dynamics multivariate OU model due deterministic approach traits towards optima. model almost identical relative fit compared multivariate unbiased random walk according AICc, competed unbiased random walk mode shift. now test complex parameterization matrix gives us better relative model fit according AICc. None models -diagonal elements matrix show better relative fit model diagonal symmetric R matrix. best model investigated remains multivariate unbiased random walk mode shift, allowing two different unbiased random walks explain trait dynamics. However, trust result, make sure run multivariate models different initial starting values, increase chances finding potentially higher peak log-likelihood surface. number iterations can defined iterations argument. starting values drawn normal distribution standard deviation one. user can define larger smaller standard deviation using argument iter.sd. trace = TRUE allows user keep eye optimization proceeds. illustrate user can define elements R matrices parameterized using function fit.multivariate.OU.user.defined, can fit lower triangle matrix symmetric R matrix. lower triangle matrix means diameter affecting optimum number ribs. elements R parameterized set zero given 1 0 respectively.

R.matrix drift matrix. options "diag" "symmetric". method optimization method, passed function optim. Default "Nelder-Mead". hess logical, indicating whether calculate standard errors Hessian matrix. trace logical, indicating whether information progress optimization printed. iterations number times optimization method run different starting points. title: Fit predefined multivariate Ornstein-Uhlenbeck models to multivariate evolutionary sequence (time-series) data. — fit.multivariate.OU
text: First part output reports log-likelihood model AICc score. second part output maximum log-likelihood model parameters (ancestral.values, optima, , R). half-life also provided,  last part output gives information number parameters model (K), number samples data (n) number times optimization routine run (iter).

title: Fit predefined multivariate Ornstein-Uhlenbeck models to multivariate evolutionary sequence (time-series) data. — fit.multivariate.OU
text: detailed explanation predefined models can fitted using function given vignette, short summary provided . Note function provides user fixed options parameterize R matrices. full flexibility, user allowed customize parameterization R matrix 'fit.multivariate.OU.user.defined' function. type trait dynamics defined based pull matrix () drift matrix (R) defined. function allows testing four broad categories models: 1 Independent evolution (.matrix ="diag", R.matrix = "diag"); 2 Independent adaptation (.matrix ="diag", R.matrix = "symmetric"); 3 Non-independent adaptation (.matrix = "upper.tri"/"lower.tri"/full", R.matrix = "diagonal"); 4 Non-independent evolution (.matrix = "upper.tri"/"lower.tri"/"full", R.matrix = "symmetric"). Setting .matrix "diagonal" means traits affect others optimum (matrix). "diagonal" R matrix means stochastic changes traits assumed uncorrelated. "symmetric" R matrix means stochastic changes traits assumed correlated, .e. non-independent. "full" parameterization estimates effect trait optima traits. "upper.tri" option parameterize model way first layer (first trait data set) adapts non-independently optimum affected traits included data set, bottom layer (last trait data set) adapts independently (Ornstein Uhlenbeck process). Layers upper- lower layer (first last trait data set (two traits data set)) evolve non-independently optimum affected layers/traits . option "lower.tri" defines causality oposite way compared "upper.tri". also possible implement model bottom layer (last trait data set) evolve Unbiased random walk (akin Brownian motion) affects optima traits data set (.e. layers except bottom layer). model can fitted defining .matrix ="OUBM", override R matrix defined. function searches - using optimization routine - maximum-likelihood solution chosen multivariate Ornstein-Uhlenbeck model. argument 'method' passed 'optim' function included convenience users better control optimization routine. Note default method (Nelder-Mead) seems work evolutionary sequences. method L-BFGS-B allows box-constraints parameters (e.g. non-negative variance parameters) faster Nelder-Mead, less stable default method (Nelder-Mead). Initial estimates start optimization come maximum-likelihood estimates univariate Ornstein-Uhlenbeck model (paleoTS package) fitted time-series separately. good practice repeat numerical optimization procedure different starting points. especially important complex models log-likelihood surface might contain one peak. number iterations controlled argument 'iterations'. function report model parameters iteration highest log-likelihood.

text: function allows users test six variants multivariate Unbiased Random Walk models. two options structure R matrix. "diagonal" R matrix means stochastic changes traits assumed uncorrelated. Initial estimates start optimization come maximum-likelihood estimates univariate Unbiased Random Walk model (paleoTS package) fitted time-series separately. good practice repeat numerical optimization procedure different starting points. especially important complex models log-likelihood surface might contain one peak. number iterations controlled argument 'iterations'. function report model parameters iteration highest log-likelihood.

title: Fit multivariate Unbiased Random Walk model. — opt.single.R
text: yy multivariate evoTS object. method optimization method, passed function optim. Default "L-BFGS-B". hess logical, indicating whether calculate standard errors Hessian matrix. trace logical, indicating whether information progress optimization printed. iterations number times optimization method run different starting points. Default NULL, meaning optimization run . iter.sd defines standard deviation Gaussian distribution starting values optimization routine run. Default 1.

title: Fit multivariate Unbiased Random Walk model. — opt.single.R
text: First part output reports log-likelihood model AICc score. second part output maximum log-likelihood model parameters (ancestral.values, R). last part output gives information number parameters model (K), number samples data (n) number times optimization routine run (iter).

title: Fit multivariate Unbiased Random Walk model. — opt.single.R
text: function searches - using optimization routine - maximum-likelihood solution multivariate Unbiased Random Walk model. argument 'method' passed 'optim' function included convenience users better control optimization routine. default method (L-BFGS-B) seems work evolutionary sequences. Initial estimates start optimization come maximum-likelihood estimates univariate Unbiased Random Walk model (paleoTS package) fitted time-series separately. good practice repeat numerical optimization procedure different starting points. especially important complex models log-likelihood surface might contain one peak. number iterations controlled argument 'iterations'. function report model parameters iteration highest log-likelihood.

title: Fit multivariate Unbiased Random Walk model. — opt.single.R
text: models implemented compatible joint parameterization routine package paleoTS. optimization therefore fit using actual sample values, autocorrelation among samples accounted log-likelihood function. joint distribution sample means multivariate normal, means variance-covariances determined evolutionary parameters sampling errors.

what: Evolutionary sequence (time-series) of phenotypic change in the number of ribs in the lineage Stephanodiscus yellowstonensis — ribs_S.yellowstonensis
title: Evolutionary sequence (time-series) of phenotypic change in the number of ribs in the lineage Stephanodiscus yellowstonensis — ribs_S.yellowstonensis
text: Phenotypic data (ribs) centric diatom lineage Stephanodiscus yellowstonensis. time series spans 14 000 years. data set contains data number costae (ribs) per valve. data consists objects class paleoTS (ribs_S.yellowstonensis). Objects class paleoTS can analyzed evoTS. object (trait data set) contains vector sample means (mm), sample variances (vv), sample sizes (nn) sample ages (tt). oldest sample listed first. data spans interval 13728 years.
